content: "http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_OBAMA_NATIONAL_SERVICE?SITE=ALMON&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT" WASHINGTON (AP) -- The AmeriCorps program started by President Bill Clinton will triple in size over the next eight years, and tens of thousands of other Americans will soon see new opportunities to give back to their communities. It's all part of a $5.7 billion national service bill President Barack Obama is scheduled to sign Tuesday to foster and fulfill people's desire to make a difference, such as by mentoring children, cleaning up parks or building and weatherizing homes for the poor. It should be tied to recieving subsidized funds from the state and federal gov loke welfare and subsidized housing as a requirement for recieving benefits but that wont happen

title: National service bill to get Obama's signature
